title: How to Put Your iPod or iPhone into DFU Mode (For All Models)

steps.title: Connect your iPod or iPhone to your computer with a USB cable.
steps.content: Connect your iPod or iPhone to your computer with a USB cable. If you can’t get this to work with a USB-C cable, you might need to use a regular USB-A cable. You can use a USB-A to USB-C adapter if necessary.

steps.title: Hold down the Side button and Volume Down button.
steps.content: Hold down the Side button and Volume Down button. Press both buttons down at once and hold them.

steps.title: Release the Side button after 8 seconds.
steps.content: Release the Side button after 8 seconds. Don’t release the Volume Down button yet! If you see the Apple logo on your iPod or iPhone at this point, you held the Side button down too long and will need to try again. If you entered DFU mode successfully, your screen should go black. You can now release the Volume Down button.

steps.title: Look for a notification on your computer.
steps.content: Look for a notification on your computer. If you have Finder or iTunes open, you may see a notification that a device was connected in recovery mode. If you see a message on your iPod or iPhone’s screen telling you to connect to Finder or iTunes, you have not successfully entered DFU mode. Repeat the steps above and try again.

steps.title: Plug your iPhone or iPod into your computer with a USB cable.
steps.content: Plug your iPhone or iPod into your computer with a USB cable. This process may not work if you use a USB-C cable. Use a Lightning to USB-A cable instead. Depending on your computer, you might need a USB-C to USB-A adapter.

steps.title: Press the Sleep/Wake button on your device for 3 seconds.
steps.content: Press the Sleep/Wake button on your device for 3 seconds. Depending on your device, this button will be at the top or side. For example, on a 6th generation iPod touch, it’s at the top of the device.

steps.title: Hold down the Sleep/Wake and Home buttons.
steps.content: Hold down the Sleep/Wake and Home buttons. After 3 seconds, press the Home button while continuing to hold down the Sleep/Wake button.

steps.title: Release the Sleep/Wake button after 8 seconds.
steps.content: Release the Sleep/Wake button after 8 seconds. Keep holding the Home button down. After you release the Sleep/Wake button, you should see a black screen on your device. If you see the Apple logo, you held down the Sleep/Wake button too long. If you have iTunes or Finder open, you may see a message that a device has been detected in recovery mode. Once you’re sure you’ve successfully entered DFU mode, you can release the Home button. If you see a message on your iPod or iPhone saying you need to connect to iTunes, you’ll need to try this process again.

steps.title: iPod classic, nano, or shuffle.
steps.content: iPod classic, nano, or shuffle. These instructions will work for the iPod classic 6th generation, the iPod nano 2nd-5th generation, or the iPod shuffle 2nd or 4th generation: Use a USB cable to plug your iPod into a computer. You’ll need a USB-A cable or a USB-A adapter. Press and hold the center and Menu buttons. Keep holding the buttons as the iPod reboots, then hold them for 8 more seconds. Release both buttons after 8 seconds.

steps.title: iPod nano 6th and 7th generation.
steps.content: iPod nano 6th and 7th generation. Use the following steps: Plug the iPod nano into your computer using a USB-A cable. Hold the Volume Down and Sleep/Wake or Home button at the same time. Use Sleep/Wake for 6th generation models, and Home for 7th generation. Hold both buttons while the device reboots. Hold them for an additional 8 seconds before releasing both buttons.

steps.title: Plug your iPhone into a computer.
steps.content: Plug your iPhone into a computer. If you have an iPhone 8 or above, getting into DFU mode is a little more complicated. Start by connecting your iPhone to your computer with a USB cable. If you can’t get this to work with a USB-C cable, use a Lightning to USB-A cable instead. You will need to use an adapter if your computer doesn’t have a USB-A port.

steps.title: Press and release the Volume Up button.
steps.content: Press and release the Volume Up button. Don’t hold the button down.

steps.title: Press and release the Volume Down button.
steps.content: Press and release the Volume Down button.

steps.title: Hold the Side button until the screen goes black.
steps.content: Hold the Side button until the screen goes black. After pressing and releasing both Volume buttons, press and hold the Side button. The screen should go blank.

steps.title: Press and hold the Side button and Volume Down button.
steps.content: Press and hold the Side button and Volume Down button. After the screen goes dark, press and hold the Volume Down Button. Keep holding the Side button at the same time.

steps.title: Release the Side button after 5 seconds.
steps.content: Release the Side button after 5 seconds. Let go of the Side button while continuing to hold the Volume Down button. If you’ve successfully entered DFU mode, you’ll see a black screen on your device. You should also see a notification in Finder or iTunes that a device has been detected in recovery mode. If you see the Apple logo or a message on your iPhone’s screen telling you to connect to iTunes, you have not successfully entered DFU mode. Try the steps above again.

steps.title: Put your device into DFU mode when downgrading.
steps.content: Put your device into DFU mode when downgrading. If you want to go back to an earlier version of iOS, you will need to enter DFU mode so that the old operating system software can be installed. DFU mode occurs before the device loads the installed operating system. This allows you to change system files while they're not being accessed.

steps.title: Put your device into DFU mode when jailbreaking.
steps.content: Put your device into DFU mode when jailbreaking. If you're jailbreaking your iPhone, you may need to put it into DFU mode to load the custom operating system. Not every jailbreak process requires you to do this.

steps.title: Put your device into DFU mode when unjailbreaking.
steps.content: Put your device into DFU mode when unjailbreaking. If you want to send in your jailbroken iPhone for warranty service, you will need to reverse the jailbreak process . This may require you to put your device into DFU mode. This is usually done as a troubleshooting step, when the device will not restore properly through iTunes.

steps.title: Put your device in DFU mode if normal recovery mode does not work.
steps.content: Put your device in DFU mode if normal recovery mode does not work. Sometimes, a firmware update may interrupt, causing corrupted files. It is advised that an iPhone or iPod is not force-restarted during a firmware update, as the device may not continue with the firmware update. However, a firmware update is interrupted or the system memory is corrupt as a result of a process like jailbreaking, DFU mode ensures that the iOS device can be restored even if the memory is corrupt.
